channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Dollar Falls on Concern Over Tariffs, US Economy: Markets Wrap
item.description: The dollar dropped, extending recent losses, on concern over the impact of higher tariffs on the US economy and the risk of a widening fiscal deficit.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

item.title: Japan Finance Ministry Is Said to Sound Out Market on Bond Sales
item.description: Japan’s finance ministry has sent a questionnaire to market participants regarding appropriate issuance amounts for government bonds, several people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Masahiro Hidaka

item.title: Thai Billionaire Hands Stakes in Major Companies to Children
item.description: Thailand’s second-richest person Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi transferred ownership of two major listed companies to his five children as the octogenarian businessman pulls back from day-to-day management of his beer-to-property conglomerate.
item.dc:creator: Anuchit Nguyen

media:content.media:description: Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi in 2014. Photographer: Dario Pignatelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Hedge Funds Bet on Korean Won to Mirror Taiwan Dollar Surge
item.description: Hedge funds are ramping up bets in the options market that the South Korean won will mirror the Taiwan dollar’s recent rally against the greenback.
item.dc:creator: David Finnerty

item.title: HK's Gaw Capital New Fund to Invest in China, Japan
item.description: Real estate-focused private equity firm Gaw Capital is looking use its new fund that could be worth $2 billion to invest in China, Japan, Australia and Vietnam. Gaw Capital Managing Principal and Global Head of Capital Markets, Christina Gaw, discusses her outlook for commercial property in Hong Kong and mainland China with David Ingles and Yvonne Man on "Bloomberg: The China Show." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Hungary To Hold Rates With Price Risks in Focus: Decision Guide
item.description: Hungary’s central bank will probably keep interest rates unchanged as policymakers focus on curbing inflation risks even as the government signals a worsening outlook for growth.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik

item.title: Iron Ore Retreats as Traders Stay Cautious on Demand Outlook
item.description: Iron ore extended its losing streak for a fourth day as traders remained cautious about demand and assessed moves to limit overcapacity in China’s steel sector.
item.dc:creator: Annie Lee, Yihui Xie

media:content.media:description: Haul trucks move iron ore at the Vale N4W mine in Parauapebas, Para state, Brazil, on Monday, May 15, 2023. Vale SA is plowing ahead with a $2.7 billion investment to expand iron output in Brazil's Amazon, betting demand for high-grade ore will stay strong in an overall softer market. Photographer: Dado Galdieri/Bloomberg

item.title: Meituan, JD.com’s Food Delivery War Worsens $100 Billion Rout
item.description: Shares of Meituan and JD.com have lost a combined $100 billion in market value since late last year, highlighting the fallout of a costly battle to win a bigger slice of the Chinese food delivery business.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

item.title: Japanese Bond Yields Decline Ahead of Test at 40-Year Auction
item.description: Yields on Japan’s super-long bonds extended their retreat to a third day amid speculation the government may consider reducing issuance of the debt after a rout last week drew global attention.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass, Masahiro Hidaka

item.title: Taiwan’s Dollar Inches Close to May Peak as Greenback Retreats
item.description: The Taiwanese dollar is edging close to a peak set earlier this month, when it notched the biggest single day gain since the 1980s.
item.dc:creator: Iris Ouyang

item.title: IndiGo’s Gangwal Seeks $1.3 Billion From Upsized Stake Sale
item.description: Rakesh Gangwal, the co-founder of India’s largest airline IndiGo, and his family trust are seeking as much as 113.85 billion rupees ($1.3 billion) from the upsized sale of a 5.7% stake in the carrier, as the billionaire continues to reduce his holding in operator InterGlobe Aviation Ltd.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fioretti

media:content.media:description: An Airbus SE A320 aircraft, operated by IndiGo, a unit of InterGlobe Aviation Ltd., prepares to land at Indira Gandhi International Airport in New Delhi, India, on Wednesday, Oct. 23, 2024. IndiGo is scheduled to release earnings results on Oct. 25.

item.title: Buyout on Hold: Seven & i Investors Eye Execution Before Backing Deal or Strategy
item.description: Seven & i Holdings Co. shareholders approved a new board at a low-key annual meeting, despite the drama surrounding a company facing a takeover proposal by Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc., the operator of Circle K stores.
item.dc:creator: Kanoko Matsuyama, Koh Yoshida

item.title: Why It Pays to Switch Jobs in HK
item.description: Recruitment agency Michael Page's latest survey shows low or stagnant salaries remain the top driver for resignations among Hong Kong professionals. The agency's managing director, Olga Yung, says employees who switch companies have seen bigger pay increases than those who choose to stay with their current employers that offer regular - if marginal - adjustments. She discuses that and other hiring trends in Hong Kong's finance sector on "Bloomberg: the China Show". (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nifty India Defence Index Hits a Record High Despite Expensive Valuations
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Savio Shetty

item.title: Cerberus Eyes Chinese Firm’s Darwin Port, the Australian Says
item.description: US private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management LP is preparing a bid for the strategically important Port of Darwin, currently owned by Chinese firm Landbridge Group, The Australian newspaper reported.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: The access entry to the Port of Darwin. Photographer: Darrian Traynor/Getty Images

item.title: Ueda Indicates BOJ Is Still Eyeing More Rate Hikes, Boosting Yen
item.description: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda gave the yen a boost by clearly indicating his intention to continue raising the benchmark interest rate if the economy improves as expected.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Kazuo Ueda in Tokyo on May 27. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Macrons Seen 'Playfighting' on Plane in Vietnam Visit
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron lands in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Sunday to start a tour of Southeast Asia. Images of him getting pushed away by his wife Brigitte Macron before disembarking their plane has made global headlines. Macron later told reporters that the couple were "squabbling" and "joking," adding that the incident was being overblown into "a sort of geo-planetary catastrophe.” (Source: The Associated Press)

item.title: Oil Steadies as Traders Focus on EU Trade Talks, OPEC+ Meeting
item.description: Oil was steady as the market weighed the prospect for easing trade tensions between the European Union and the US ahead of an OPEC+ meeting that will make a decision on supply policy.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: A tank at the Burnaby Terminal in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada, on Saturday, Feb. 24, 2024. With an expansion of the Trans Mountain crude pipeline set to start operation in the months ahead, the supply of western Canadian oil available for export is set to rise by about 500,000 barrels a day by the end of next year, S&P Global estimates. Photographer: Paige Taylor White/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Plastics Buyers Resist Switch Back to US Propane Despite Pause in Trade War
item.description: Chinese plastics factories left without US raw material when trade relations collapsed earlier this year are holding back from returning to many of those suppliers despite a pause in hostilities, underscoring the difficulty in restoring commercial ties between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Lua, Serene Cheong

item.title: Dai-Ichi Life Sees JGB Market Volatility Declining
item.description: The surging bond yields that have saddled Japan’s insurers with billions of dollars in unrealized losses will weaken because they are not supported by economic fundamentals, according to Dai-ichi Life Holdings Inc., the country’s largest listed life insurer.
item.dc:creator: Taiga Uranaka, Nao Sano

media:content.media:description: Signage for Dai-ichi Life Group in a reception area at the Dai-ichi Life Holdings Inc. and Dai-ichi Life Insurance Co. head office building in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, Jan. 19, 2024. Japanese life insurers are the main buyers of domestic sovereign bonds due in more than 10 years and typically increase purchases toward the end of the fiscal year. They are holding off as the earthquake that struck Ishikawa Prefecture on Jan. 1 reduced the likelihood that the BOJ will end negative rates at its meeting on Jan. 23.

item.title: ALS to Raise Up to A$390 Million to Grow Laboratory Network
item.description: Australia’s ALS Ltd. is seeking to raise up to A$390 million ($253 million) as the testing services company looks to expand its laboratory network.
item.dc:creator: Carmeli Argana

item.title: Gold Holds Decline as EU-US Trade Talks Weigh on Haven Demand
item.description: Gold held a small decline as demand for haven assets cooled, with investors weighing prospects for improving trade relations between the US and the EU.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

item.title: Hong Kong Bourse Plans to Start Zero-Day Options Trading in 2026
item.description: Hong Kong’s stock exchange is seeking to launch options that expire within a day as early as the first half of 2026, bringing to the Asian hub an instrument that has driven a boom in US derivatives in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Savio Shetty

item.title: Xiaomi’s Peer-Beating Rally Sets High Bar Ahead of Earnings
item.description: It’ll be tough for Xiaomi Corp. to beat investors’ already high expectations when it reports earnings later Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Yang

media:content.media:description: Xiaomi Corp. SU7 electric vehicles on display at one of the company's store in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, April 2, 2024. Xiaomi surged in Hong Kong as orders for its first electric vehicle topped estimates, fueling optimism the smartphone maker may succeed in China's cutthroat car market.

item.title: Wildfires Erupt Near Alberta Oil Well Sites Amid Hot Weather
item.description: Hot weather sparked a string of wildfires around Alberta over the weekend, including some near oil and gas wells operated by Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. and others.
item.dc:creator: Robert Tuttle

media:content.media:description: The SWF076 wildfire, located north of Swan Hills, Alberta, Canada, in this photo release by Alberta Wildfire on May 26, 2025.

item.title: Stocks Rise on Trump’s Tariff Delay; Dollar Wavers: Markets Wrap
item.description: European stocks climbed along with US equity futures after President Donald Trump extended a deadline on aggressive euro area tariffs, reinforcing a pattern of leaving markets guessing by making trade threats before backtracking.
item.dc:creator: Robert Brand

media:content.media:description: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during the Hinge Health Inc. initial public offering (IPO) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 22, 2025. Hinge Health Inc. and a group of investors raised $437 million in the digital physical therapy provider's US initial public offering, pricing shares at the top of a marketed range.

item.title: Gauge of EM Currencies Rises as Dollar Slips on Thin Trading
item.description: A gauge for emerging-market currencies gained as President Donald Trump’s move to extend a deadline for aggressive tariffs on the European Union bolstered risk appetite, in a session marked by thin trading volumes due to holidays in the US and the UK.
item.dc:creator: Jaehyun Eom, Srinivasan Sivabalan, Giovanna Bellotti Azevedo

item.title: King Charles Visits Canada as Country Rattled by Trump Taunts
item.description: King Charles III arrived in Canada to open a new parliamentary session at the invitation of Prime Minister Mark Carney, a move designed in part to send a message to US President Donald Trump about the northern country’s sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: King Charles III and Queen Camilla arrive at Ottawa Airport on Monday.

item.title: US Money Managers Put on Notice by $65 Billion Dutch Investor
item.description: Dutch pension fund PME is issuing a blanket warning to US money managers, amid concerns America’s investment industry is caving in to pressure from the Trump administration to abandon basic principles of stewardship.
item.dc:creator: Frances Schwartzkopff

media:content.media:description: President Trump signs executive orders during a ceremony in the Oval Office following the inauguration of his second term.

item.title: Oil Swings as Market Weighs Easing Trade Tensions, OPEC+ Outlook
item.description: Oil fluctuated as the market weighed easing trade tensions against the outlook for rising OPEC+ supply.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen, Rakteem Katakey
